subject: RE: [junit] Re: ClassNotFoundException
msgSnippet: Generally, they _will_ be empty.  The magic here is that by including the project directory in the workspace classpath you automagically gets the project
messageBody:
Generally, they _will_ be empty. The magic here is that by including the
project directory in the workspace classpath you automagically gets the
project included as well.

Also, I don't run tests with JUnit class files or the JUnit jar. I import
the source into VAJ, include the project into the workspace classpath
(through one of the two ways already mentioned), write the .ini and away we
go.

What most folks don't know is that you don't have to add any class files to
the file system at all for VAJ tools to work. As long as the class the tool
is referencing is in the workspace classpath VAJ will find it. This has
several obvious advantages (real time recompilation, powerful debugging
support, etc.) and some disadvantages (needs to be compiled every time, so
start up is somewhat slower, but noticeable only if you have a low
memory/resources machine, etc.).

-Jason

> --- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@t...> wrote:
> > If you are running in VAJ, just add the
> project_resources folder
> for all
> > projects into your workspace classpath or dynamically load all
> projects into
> > the workspace classpath. Here is a class that will run
> JUnit like
> this,
> > edit your JUnit tool's default.ini to point to this class.
> >
> >
> > package <your package>;
> >
> > import junit.<your favorite ui>.*;
> >
> > public class JUnitLauncher {
> > public JUnitLauncher() {}
> > public static void main(String args[]) {
> > JUnitLauncher.setClassPath();
> > TestRunner.main(args);
> > }
> > /**
> > * Update the classpath to include all workspace projects.
> > */
> > public void setClassPath() throws IvjException {
> >
> > Workspace workspace = ToolEnv.connectToWorkspace();
> > Object[] classpath = workspace.getClassPathEntries();
> > Object[] projects = workspace.getProjects();
> > Object[] newClasspath = new Object[classpath.length +
> > projects.length];
> >
> > //add the projects to the new classpath
> > System.arraycopy(projects, 0, newClasspath, 0,
> projects.length);
> >
> > //add the original classpath to the new classpath
> > System.arraycopy(classpath, 0, newClasspath,
> projects.length,
> > classpath.length);
> >
> > try {
> > workspace.setClassPath(newClasspath);
> > } catch(IvjException e) {
> > e.printStackTrace();
> > }
> >
> > }
> > }
> >
